tr.td: History of changes made to the attributes of an issue.
Attachment is a piece of information associated with an issue.
Possible types of attachements. Example: Comment Example: File
Possible attributes of an issue. Example: Operating System Example: Severity
Attribute class is group of attributes types that have the same properties. Example: Free form input. Example: Select one from the list.
Groupings in which attributes appear on the page.
Attribute option is possible value of an attribute of an issue. Example: DOS 3.1 (for attribute Operating System)
Attribute type is group of attributes that have the same representation in the application data structure. Attribute type fully defines attribute behavior. Example: Integer Example: String
Dependency between issues. Example: Issue is a duplicate of another issue. Example: Issue is blocking another issue.
Possible types of dependency between issues. Example: Duplicate Example: Block
Frequencies of an event. Examples: every half hour, weekly.
Information about artifact under processing in tracking system. Example: Particular defect Example: Particular inquiry
Actual attribute of the issue with its value.
A saved user template for entering issues.
The number of votes a user has cast for an issue.
Modification information for table. Not currently used.
Logical category of issues. Usually corresponds to the software project. Example: Scarab
Possible types of dependency between options. Example: Parent-Child Example: Requires
Attributes that are applicable to issues of the particular module.
Mapping between modules and issue types.
Options that are applicable to issues of the particular module.
User's choice of attributes to appear on the Issue List screen.
Transaction is a group of attribute modification that are performed together.
Possible types of transactions. Example: Issue Created Example: Issue Moved
This table is used to store user preferences and other information relating to a specific user.
A user's record of votes. It is assumed that a module that supports voting will give a new user some votes to use when the user is added, otherwise the user has no votes.

Dummy table for where the USER_ID lives. In most cases, this will be a foreign table outside of the scope of Scarab itself. For example, if you are using Scarab with Turbine, then this will be defined as TURBINE_USER. For use in other systems, you will want to define this to be the name of your own USER table and update the FK references in this file to point at the new name. Then, all you need to do is regenerate the OR code to use the new table name.

subsection.name: Description:
subsection.p: History of changes made to the attributes of an issue.

tr.td: Date this Activity is no longer the current value of the Attribute.
Issue attribute of which has been modified.
Value of integer attribute after modification.
Value of option attribute after modification.
Value of user attribute after modification.
Value of integer attribute before modification.
Value of option attribute before modification.
Value of user attribute before modification.
Transaction to which the attribute modification belongs.

subsection.name: Description:
subsection.p: Attachment is a piece of information associated with an issue.

tr.td: Server side location of the file that contains attachment. Location is relative to the central file storage location specified in the application properties.
MIME type of the attachment. Describes type of information constituting an attachment.
Name that is displayed in the UI.
Person that associated the attachment with an issue initially.
Date of the initial association of attachment with an issue.
Flag, which marks that attachment has been deleted.
Issue that attachment is associated with.
Person that made last modification to the attachment.
Date of the last modification of the attachment.

subsection.name: Description:
subsection.p: Possible types of attachements. Example: Comment Example: File

subsection.name: Description:
subsection.p: Possible attributes of an issue. Example: Operating System Example: Severity

tr.td: For user attributes, whether the user will be emailed, cc'd, or neither.
Person that set value to the column of the table initially.
Date of the initial set of the column of the table.
Flag, which marks that attribute has been deleted.
A permission related to this attribute.
A required option for this attribute to be active.

subsection.name: Description:
subsection.p: Attribute class is group of attributes types that have the same properties. Example: Free form input. Example: Select one from the list.

tr.td: Fully qualified name of the java class that represents attribute, belonging to the attribute class, in the application.

subsection.name: Description:
subsection.p: Groupings in which attributes appear on the page.

subsection.name: Description:
subsection.p: Attribute option is possible value of an attribute of an issue. Example: DOS 3.1 (for attribute Operating System)

tr.td: Attribute that can take the options as its value.
Flag, which marks that option has been deleted.

subsection.name: Description:
subsection.p: Attribute type is group of attributes that have the same representation in the application data structure. Attribute type fully defines attribute behavior. Example: Integer Example: String

tr.td: Fully qualified name of the java class that represents attribute, belonging to the attribute type, in the application.
A key which ties into a validation service (intake).

subsection.name: Description:
subsection.p: Dependency between issues. Example: Issue is a duplicate of another issue. Example: Issue is blocking another issue.

tr.td: Issue that other issue depends upon. Example: Issue that blocks. Example: Issue that has duplicates.
Issue that depends on other issue. Example: Issue that is being blocked. Example: Issue that is duplicate.
Flag, which marks that dependency has been deleted.

subsection.name: Description:
subsection.p: Possible types of dependency between issues. Example: Duplicate Example: Block

subsection.name: Description:
subsection.p: Frequencies of an event. Examples: every half hour, weekly.

subsection.name: Description:
subsection.p: Information about artifact under processing in tracking system. Example: Particular defect Example: Particular inquiry

tr.td: Unique identifier used for primary key.
Flag, which marks that issue has been deleted.
Part of Id which is an integer.
The instance of scarab the issue was originally reported to. This field could be null for the normal instance where the issue is local to this database.
Part of Id related to module.
Type : Issue, or Enter Issue Template.

subsection.name: Description:
subsection.p: Actual attribute of the issue with its value.

tr.td: Flag, which marks that attribute has been deleted.
some attributes are better saved in numeric format, so this column can be used in place of VALUE.
Option that is the value of the attribute if attribute is option based.
Person that is the value of the attribute if attribute is person based.

Display value of the attribute. This column should always contain a value which serves as a 'summary value' of the attribute, you MAY need to look elsewhere to get real value. Purpose of this 'duplication' is to be able to get overview of the attribute independently of what kind of attribute this is. This also improves performance so you do not need to perform (sometimes complex) processing each time you view the issue. It lets you get list of issues with their attributes with a single SQL statement. Examples of what would go into this fields for different kinds of attributes: - For 'free-form' attributes this would be the actual value (it's String representation to be exact) - For 'select-one' this would be a copy of value in SCARAB_ATTRIBUTE_OPTION.DISPLAY_VALUE. There will also be an apropriate value in OPTION_ID column which you should use to join with SCARAB_ATTRIBUTE_OPTION - For 'voted' attributes this would be the vote result. For bugzilla-style votes it is sum of all votes casted. For average vote this result is DISPLAY_VALUE of OPTION which has computed as: round(sum(votes.numeric_value)/count(votes)). For 'Tracking' attribute which is also considered a voted attribute this value is a list of login_IDs of users tracking the issue. It is responsibility of Attribute's subclass which implements this ATTRIBUTE_TYPE to populate this field with an apropriate value.

subsection.name: Description:
subsection.p: A saved user template for entering issues.

tr.td: The description of the saved template.
Unique identifier used for primary key.
If this issue type is a template, the id of the issue type it Corresponds to. If is not, parent id is 0.

subsection.name: Description:
subsection.p: The number of votes a user has cast for an issue.

tr.td: The votes a user has cast for the issue.

subsection.name: Description:
subsection.p: Modification information for table. Not currently used.

tr.td: Person that set value to the column of the table initially.
Date of the initial set of the column of the table.
Person that made last modification to the column of the table.
Date of the last modification of the column of the table.

subsection.name: Description:
subsection.p: Logical category of issues. Usually corresponds to the software project. Example: Scarab

tr.td: Flag, which marks that module has been deleted.
The instance name of scarab the module is located within.
Abbreviation whose primary use to identify related issues.

Name. It is RealName because Module implements the Turbine Group interface and having it as Name would clash with that interface. Please note that the result of group.getName() needs to be unique for each SCARAB_MODULE.
URL pointing to the information on the module.
Person that is responsible for the module. @deprecated.
Parent module containing the module. Allows for hierarchical structure of modules.
Key quality assurance person for the module. @deprecated.

subsection.name: Description:
subsection.p: Possible types of dependency between options. Example: Parent-Child Example: Requires

subsection.name: Description:
subsection.p: A saved user query.

tr.td: The description of the saved query.
The name the query will be saved under.

subsection.name: Description:
subsection.p: Mapping from attributes to groups.

subsection.name: Description:
subsection.p: Attributes that are applicable to issues of the particular module.

tr.td: Flag, which marks that module attribute is not used.
Flag, which marks that this attribute should be used in the email subject line, when an issue is created. May be used in other contexts as well.
Value that represents the attribute in the UI.
Flag, which marks this attribute as being eligible for quick search.
Flag, which marks that issues entered for this module must have this attribute set.

subsection.name: Description:
subsection.p: Mapping between modules and issue types.

tr.td: Flag, which marks that the issue type is not used.
Whether or not the issue type shows up in left hand nav.
Value that represents the description of the issue type in the UI.
Value that represents the name of the issue type in the UI.
Order the the issue types appear in the left nav.

subsection.name: Description:
subsection.p: Options that are applicable to issues of the particular module.

tr.td: Flag, which marks that option has been deleted within the module.
Value that represents the option in the UI.
Allows the template engineer and module owner some means to order option listings.

subsection.name: Description:
subsection.p: User's choice of attributes to appear on the Issue List screen.

subsection.name: Description:
subsection.p: Sets up relations between options.

tr.td: The preferred order that these options should be shown in. Each option should have a 1-N ordering for all of its options (regardless of nesting).
The type of relationship. See the SCARAB_OPTION_RELATIONSHIP table for the different types.

This gives 'weight' to an option. In other words, it can be used to set the 'importance' of one option vs. another option. P1 can be made more 'important' than P2. This is currently not used in any of the code. This may become more useful in the future when we have outside workflow logic. This is placed here because an Attribute Option may have different weights with different parents.

subsection.name: Description:
subsection.p: Users subscribed to a query.

tr.td: Whether this is the user's default query.

subsection.name: Description:
subsection.p: A saved report.

tr.td: The description of the saved report.
The name the report will be saved under.

subsection.name: Description:
subsection.p: Scope: personal, global.

subsection.name: Description:
subsection.p: Transaction is a group of attribute modification that are performed together.

subsection.name: Description:
subsection.p: Possible types of transactions. Example: Issue Created Example: Issue Moved

subsection.name: Description:
subsection.p: This table is used to store user preferences and other information relating to a specific user.

tr.td: This is a column that Scarab standalone needs. Torque doesn't do anything with it at this point because this is an aliased table. Leaving it in here just as an FYI and in the hope that one day, Torque will generate the right methods even for aliased tables.

subsection.name: Description:
subsection.p: A user's record of votes. It is assumed that a module that supports voting will give a new user some votes to use when the user is added, otherwise the user has no votes.

tr.td: The total votes a user is allowed to cast in a project.
The number of votes a user has cast in a project.

subsection.name: Description:
subsection.p: Dummy table for where the USER_ID lives. In most cases, this will be a foreign table outside of the scope of Scarab itself. For example, if you are using Scarab with Turbine, then this will be defined as TURBINE_USER. For use in other systems, you will want to define this to be the name of your own USER table and update the FK references in this file to point at the new name. Then, all you need to do is regenerate the OR code to use the new table name.
